qas.question: How many current students take Chinese courses at Eaton?
Is Chinese a required or non-curriculum course?
How many computers were at Eaton in the 1970s?
Which subject was only studied by boys with sufficient ability?
Was was the emphasis early on?
In what decade was learning Chinese introduced to Eton?
How many students at Eton now learn Latin each year?
In the past how many students each year learned Classical Greek?

context: Later the emphasis was on <b4_0>classical studies<b4_0/>, dominated by Latin and Ancient History, and, for boys with sufficient ability, <a3_0>Classical Greek<a3_0/>. From the latter part of the 19th century this curriculum has changed and broadened: for example, there are now <a0_0><b7_0>more <b6_0>than 100<b7_0/><b6_0/><a0_0/> students of Chinese, which is a <a1_0>non-curriculum<a1_0/> course. In the <b5_0>1970s<b5_0/>, there was <a2_0>just one<a2_0/> school computer, in a small room attached to the science buildings. It used paper tape to store programs. Today, all boys must have laptop computers, and the school fibre-optic network connects all classrooms and all boys' bedrooms to the internet.
